author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Russia Agree to Keep a Lid on Oil Production, Sending Prices Higher
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies stuck with current quotas for April, with some exceptions. Saudi Arabia offered a similar compromise to the one it reached with Russia in January.
content: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies set aside proposals for expanding output and decided on Thursday to keep a tight rein on production, sticking with current quotas for April with some exceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Party Down,’ a Cult Hit, Is Getting a Revival on Starz
description: The short-lived but beloved sitcom about a team of misanthropic cater-waiters will be revived with a six-episode limited series.
content: The short-lived Starz sitcom “Party Down,” about a team of misanthropic cater-waiters in Los Angeles, aired in 2009 and 2010 in relative obscurity, then turned into a cult hit in the years since its cancellation. Now, the show will be revived with a six-episode limited series, Starz said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Catie Edmondson and Karen Zraick
title: The House passes a policing overhaul bill named for George Floyd, whose death spurred nationwide protests.
description: The bill is aimed at combating racial discrimination and excessive use of force in law enforcement. But its prospects are dim in the Senate.
content: House Democrats passed a sweeping federal policing overhaul on Wednesday that would combat racial discrimination and excessive use of force in law enforcement, as lawmakers seek to rekindle bipartisan negotiations on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Coral Davenport
title: Biden’s interior secretary pick, Deb Haaland, is headed to confirmation as two Republicans announce support.
description: The support of Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, a key Republican from an oil-producing state, virtually ensures Ms. Haaland’s confirmation by the Senate.
content: A Senate committee on Thursday approved Deb Haaland to be the next secretary of the interior, with the support of Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, a key Republican from an oil-producing state, virtually ensuring her confirmation by the Senate later this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: In Reconciliation Act, Macron Acknowledges Truth of Algerian Lawyer’s Death
description: The president admitted that Ali Boumendjel did not die by suicide, as France had previously claimed, but was killed by French troops during the Algerian war of independence.
content: PARIS — Emmanuel Macron, the first French president born after the brutal Algerian war of independence, has taken a further step toward reconciliation through truth by declaring that a leading Algerian lawyer and nationalist did not die by suicide in 1957, as France had long claimed, but was tortured and killed by French soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The man who put his feet up on a desk in Pelosi’s office during the Capitol riot throws a tantrum in court.
description: Richard Barnett yelled at the judge and his own lawyers that it wasn’t “fair” that he was still in jail weeks after his arrest.
content: Richard Barnett, the Arkansas man charged with breaking into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office and stealing her mail during the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, threw a tantrum during a virtual court hearing on Thursday, yelling at the judge and his own lawyers that it wasn’t “fair” that he was still in jail weeks after his arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘F.T.A.’: When Jane Fonda Rocked the U.S. Army
description: A newly exhumed documentary delves into the actress’s anti-Vietnam vaudeville tour of American military bases in 1972.
content: “F.T.A.,” an agitprop rockumentary that ran for a week in July 1972, reappears as an exhumed relic, recording the joyfully scurrilous anti-Vietnam War vaudeville led by Jane Fonda that toured the towns outside American military bases in Hawaii, the Philippines and Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Winnie Hu
title: As Online Shopping Surged, Amazon Planned Its New York Takeover
description: The e-commerce giant added at least nine new warehouses in the city over the past year as 2.4 million packages a day strained the nation’s largest urban delivery system.
content: When the pandemic gripped New York City, it propelled an enormous surge in online shopping that has not waned, even in a metropolis where stores are rarely far away. People who regularly bought online are now buying more, while those who started ordering to avoid exposure to the virus have been won over by the advantages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: North Carolina Officer Slams Dog Into Car, Prompting Investigation
description: A video obtained by a TV station appears to show an officer in Salisbury, N.C., hoisting a police dog off the ground by its leash and shoving it into the side of an S.U.V.
content: A police department in North Carolina has ordered an investigation into a video that appeared to show an officer lifting a police dog off the ground by its leash during a training exercise and slamming the dog into the side of a patrol car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The Truffle Hunters’ Review: In Dogged Pursuit of Culinary Gold
description: An enchanting documentary about men and their best friends combing the northern Italian forests for an unlikely delicacy.
content: The history of human gastronomy is full of mysteries. Who figured out that an oyster was something to eat? That fruit juice left sitting around for a while would get you drunk? That a kid would eat the middle of an Oreo first? I am now convinced that these imponderables pale in comparison to the question of the truffle. How did this subterranean fungus, the best specimens of which look like woebegone potatoes, come to be among the most prized and pricey of delicacies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave, Neil Vigdor and Natasha Frost
title: Tsunami Warning Lifted for New Zealand After 8.1-Magnitude Earthquake
description: The temblor was one of three powerful earthquakes that were recorded within eight hours in the South Pacific off New Zealand, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
content: SYDNEY — A tsunami warning for parts of New Zealand was lifted on Friday afternoon, hours after officials had told residents of coastal areas to evacuate in the wake of an 8.1-magnitude earthquake in the South Pacific.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: In Iceland, 18,000 Earthquakes Over Days Signal Possible Eruption on the Horizon
description: The earthquake swarm is the culmination of more than a year of intense seismic activity. It could also herald decades of intermittent volcanic eruptions.
content: Volcanoes in southwestern Iceland have been quiet for 800 years, but the period of rest may soon be over: More than 18,000 earthquakes have shaken the area in just over a week, leading scientists to believe that an eruption could be imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Close Is the Pandemic’s End?
description: As President Biden accelerates plans for manufacturing vaccines and several states move to reopen, we check in on the virus.
content: It’s been almost a year since the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Officials Put ‘Unusual’ Limits on D.C. National Guard Before Riot, Commander Says
description: Maj. Gen. William J. Walker testified that he did not receive permission to deploy troops for hours on Jan. 6, as violence by pro-Trump supporters escalated.
content: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials placed “unusual” restrictions on the D.C. National Guard before the Capitol riot, its commander told senators on Wednesday, saying the military leaders’ fears of a repeat of aggressive tactics used during racial justice protests last year slowed decision-making and squandered time as the violence by a pro-Trump mob escalated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: ‘Overlooked My Whole Life’: H.B.C.U. Set Stage for an N.B.A. Career
description: The only active N.B.A. player from a historically Black college or university, Robert Covington is making a name for himself.
content: Robert Covington remembers his college basketball practices. He remembers the two-on-one full-court drills where he was the “one” and had to try to defend two teammates. He remembers the endless games of one on one that more closely approximated cage matches. He remembers breaking curfew to sneak into the gym to work on his shot — and the late-night phone calls to his coaches when campus security caught him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Kellen Winslow II, Once N.F.L.’s Highest-Paid Tight End, Gets 14 Years for Rapes
description: The sentencing judge called the former Cleveland Browns player a sexual predator who preyed on marginalized women.
content: Kellen Winslow II, once the highest-paid tight end in the National Football League as a key player for the Cleveland Browns, was sentenced on Wednesday to 14 years in prison for raping two women and sex crimes against three others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: How Do Blind Worms See the Color Blue?
description: Eyeless roundworms may have hacked other cellular warning systems to give themselves a form of color vision.
content: In the warm, fetid environs of a compost heap, tiny roundworms feast on bacteria. But some of these microbes produce toxins, and the worms avoid them. In the lab, scientists curious about how the roundworms can tell what’s dinner and what’s dangerous often put them on top of mats of various bacteria to see if they wriggle away. One microbe species, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, reliably sends them scurrying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden’s honeymoon is over, but he retains majority approval, a poll found.
description: The president’s approval rating now stands at 51 percent nationwide, with 42 percent of the country disapproving, according to a Monmouth University poll.
content: Whatever honeymoon period he may have briefly enjoyed, President Biden is now past it, according to the results of a Monmouth University poll released this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahim Abed
title: Afghan War Casualty Report: March 2021
description: At least 21 pro-government forces and 22 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
content: At least 21 pro-government forces and 22 civilians were killed in Afghanistan the past week. The deadliest attack took place in Kunduz Province, where the Taliban attacked a security outpost in the Telawka area of the Sixth Police District in Kunduz city, the provincial capital, killing eight soldiers and wounding four others. The Taliban captured the outpost and seized weapons and equipment, including two Humvees. In Nangarhar Province, unknown gunmen entered a plaster factory in the Mar Ghondi area of Surkh Rod District, killing seven workers who were Hazara. The gunmen first tied the hands and legs of all seven civilians and then shot them with a suppressed pistol. Local officials in Nangarhar believed that the attack was carried out by the Islamic State affiliated group. In another attack in the province, three women who worked at a local television network were shot and killed in two different attacks in the First Police District of Jalalabad city, the provincial capital. All three women were working in the dubbing section of the television network. Another woman was also wounded in the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: What Makes a Good Leader, and Who Gets to Be One?
description: With a focus on compassion, empathy and humility, the book “Vital Voices” challenges long-held assumptions about power and how we wield it.
content: — From the poem “Vital Voices” by Amanda Gorman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: How to Reach People Who Are Wrong
description: In the post-Trump era, research suggests the best ways to win people over.
content: The Trump years were a time of high passion, of moral certainty, of drawing lines in the sand, of despair at the ethical and intellectual vacuity of political foes. But now it’s time to recalibrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serena Solomon
title: At America’s Cup, Auckland Laments the Boats That Didn’t Come
description: With strict coronavirus rules keeping out superyachts and their wealthy owners, New Zealand’s marine industry is missing both their glamour and their money.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — As the executive director of a marine trades organization, Peter Busfield makes it his business to know which superyachts are sailing to New Zealand because of their high value to his members and their businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viridiana Ríos
title: Mexican Women Are Fed Up and The President Doesn’t Get It
description: Andrés Manuel López Obrador is supporting a candidate accused of rape. Women may need to give up on him.
content: MEXICO CITY — President Andrés Manuel López Obrador is in the middle of a political storm. His party nominated Félix Salgado Macedonio, who has been accused by five women of rape and sexual harassment, as a candidate for governor of Guerrero State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: New Yorkers say that Cuomo shouldn’t resign, but that he shouldn’t run for re-election either.
description: By a margin of 55 percent to 40 percent, participants in a new poll said they didn’t think Gov. Andrew Cuomo should resign. But by an even wider margin, most said they didn’t want him to run again, either.
content: Reeling from multiple scandals and faced with crescendoing calls for his resignation, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has managed to retain the support of most voters in his state. But that support appears to come with a time limit attached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: ‘Nobody Is in Charge’: Capitol’s Secretive Police Board Faces Overhaul After Riot
description: Top lawmakers say the Capitol Police Board, which is beholden to House and Senate leaders, needs significant changes after the security failures of Jan. 6.
content: WASHINGTON — The congressional inquiry into the security failures surrounding the Jan. 6 Capitol assault has barely begun, but one outcome already seems certain: The Capitol Police Board, the secretive three-member panel that oversees protection of the complex where Congress meets, is headed for major changes, if not outright elimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: C.I.A. to Expand Inquiry Into Mysterious Health Episodes Overseas
description: A task force will push for better care for officers injured in unexplained incidents in Cuba, China and Russia that have caused an illness known as Havana syndrome.
content: WASHINGTON — A new C.I.A. task force is trying to expand efforts to find the cause of a series of mysterious incidents that injured its officers around the world, the agency said this week, episodes that have occurred in Cuba, China, Russia and elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.

author: By Kim Severson
title: Texas Farmers Tally Up the Damage From a Winter Storm ‘Massacre’
description: The state’s agriculture sector has lost an estimated $600 million or more. Crop and livestock damage could mean shortages and higher prices beyond Texas.
content: Texas farmers and ranchers have lost at least $600 million to the winter storm that struck the state last month, according to an assessment issued this week by economists at the Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Stray’ Review: Nothing but a Hound Dog
description: Elizabeth Lo’s thoughtful documentary uses the stray dogs of Istanbul to comment on the human condition.
content: Zeytin has a strong head, hazel eyes and a quizzical expression. Long-legged and confident, she trots beside busy highways, unbothered by crowds or the director Elizabeth Lo’s trailing camera. Why should she be? She’s a star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert: QAnon Supporters Suffer From ‘March Madness’
description: Colbert poked fun at the group’s latest conspiracy theory that March 4 would be Donald Trump’s true Inauguration Day.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope’s Planned Visit to Iraq, Amid Pandemic, Raises Questions of Timing
description: Pope Francis has said he is determined to visit the war-torn country. But some worry that the visit will become a superspreader event in a land where the virus still rages.
content: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis has said that he has canceled trips during the pandemic because “in conscience I cannot provoke gatherings,” but that the only thing that would stop him from becoming the first pope to visit war-scarred Iraq would be a new surge in infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Heather McGhee Knows Readers Judge Books by Their Covers
description: The author of “The Sum of Us” did not want her new best seller to look like a book that was only intended for one kind of reader.
content: DIVE IN Like most authors, Heather McGhee had strong opinions about what her book’s cover should look like. This former president of Demos, a progressive think tank, was well aware that “The Sum of Us,” her exploration of the economics of racism, had the potential to be packaged in a dry, boring way that would appeal to a narrow audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa S. Kearney and Phillip B. Levine
title: We Expect 300,000 Fewer Births Than Usual This Year
description: Signs are pointing to a sizable pandemic baby bust in the United States, with implications that will be with us for years to come.
content: The Covid-19 pandemic has thrown the country into an economic recession and an unprecedented restructuring of our work and social lives. Early on, some likened the public health crisis to a blizzard, imagining that people would stay home, cozy up with their romantic partners and make babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Latest Case of Vaccine Alarmism
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: It’s the latest case of vaccine alarmism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Stacey Abrams on American Idealism and American Betrayal
description: Abrams helped win major Democratic victories in Georgia, the right is retaliating and it’s getting personal. But Abrams says she doesn’t mind; it’s all about the long game.
content: Stacey Abrams’s focus on expanding voter turnout and turning Georgia blue paid off this year when Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock both flipped Senate seats, handing Democrats a slim majority in Congress. Republicans are fighting back quickly and with force, introducing bills to restrict voting in Georgia and 42 other states. Ms. Abrams says she’s combating their efforts by promoting federal legislation like H.R.1, titled the For the People Act, an omnibus election-reform bill that just passed in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Shiona Turini’s beauty secrets, a boutique hotel in Oaxaca — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: BAM Helped Buy Its Boss a New Home. She Left in Under 6 Years.
description: Some cultural institutions own apartments for their leaders to use. The Brooklyn Academy of Music decided to help its last leader buy one with a bonus of $968,000.
content: One of the perks of leading premier cultural institutions, besides the substantial salaries, is the use of elegant apartments, which are often owned by arts organizations and passed from one top executive to the next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Lost Course’ Review: When a Village Fights Back
description: A 2011 revolt in Wukan, China, is the subject of a sobering, sprawling documentary.
content: “Lost Course” uses a local uprising that made international headlines to pose broader questions about the feasibility of democratic and anticorruption reforms in China. This sobering, sprawling documentary — the first feature from Jill Li, who took the time to follow her subjects over several years — splits its three hours into before-and-after categories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The United States suspends tariffs on Scotch whisky and other British products.
description: A 25 percent tariff was placed on Scotch whisky in October 2019, and  exports to the United States have since dropped 35 percent.
content: The United States will suspend retaliatory tariffs against Britain for four months, including on Scotch whisky, arising from the longstanding trade dispute about subsidies for Boeing and Airbus. The two governments said they would use the time to try to come up with a long-term solution to the trade disagreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: How Berkeley Beat Back NIMBYs
description: Is California finally ready to accept a more sustainable way of life?
content: A century ago, the civic leaders of Berkeley, Calif., pioneered what would become one of America’s most enduring systems of racial inequity — a soft apartheid of zoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: ‘She Is a Hero’: In Myanmar’s Protests, Women Are on the Front Lines
description: Despite the danger, women have been at the forefront of the movement, rebuking the generals who ousted a female civilian leader.
content: Ma Kyal Sin loved taekwondo, spicy food and a good red lipstick. She adopted the English name Angel, and her father hugged her goodbye when she went out on the streets of Mandalay, in central Myanmar, to join the crowds peacefully protesting the recent seizure of power by the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Her Eyelid Drooped and She Kept Getting Weaker. What Was Going On?
description: Dozens of tests turned up nothing. Then a specialist had a theory.
content: The voice on the phone was kind but firm: “You need to go to the emergency room. Now.” Her morning was going to be busy, replied the 68-year-old woman, and she didn’t feel well. Could she go later today or maybe tomorrow? No, said Dr. Benison Keung, her neurologist. She needed to go now; it was important. As she hung up the phone, tears blurred the woman’s already bad vision. She’d been worried for a while; now she was terrified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: The Era of Audio Creators Has Arrived
description: A new company called Audio Collective has launched to help build businesses on Clubhouse as brands rush to leverage the platform.
content: Audio creators are a new kind of influencer, born of the meteoric rise of the audio-only chat app Clubhouse. Together, they are pulling in millions of weekly listeners and building online followings. Now, with Clubhouse booming and other social apps, like Twitter, taking cues from its success, they are banding together and working with big brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Dallas Museum of Art to Return Sacred Statue to Nepal
description: The museum is returning the sculpture, which was looted from a temple in the 1980s. The move comes after researchers raised concerns about its provenance.
content: A stone sculpture representing a Hindu deity is making its way back to Nepal nearly 40 years after it disappeared from a temple shrine and ended up in the Dallas Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Narrow Stimulus Payments as Biden Works to Keep Aid Plan on Track
description: President Biden blessed the plan to lower the income cap for Americans receiving checks of up to $1,400, a crucial concession to moderates whose backing is needed to pass the bill.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden agreed on Wednesday to place stricter income limits on the next round of stimulus payments, making the latest in a series of crucial concessions to moderates as Democrats worked to hold their fragile coalition together to push his $1.9 trillion pandemic aid package through a divided Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Biden Is the Anti-Trump, and It’s Working
description: If you can dial down the conflict, you can dial up the policy.
content: American politics feels quieter with Joe Biden in the White House. The president’s Twitter feed hasn’t gone dark, but it’s gone dull. Biden doesn’t pick needless fights or insert himself into cultural conflicts. It’s easy to go days without hearing anything the president has said, unless you go looking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How a Holocaust Survivor Showed Up for a Vaccine and Charmed a Hospital
description: Mira Rosenblatt, 97, stunned nurses with her tale of endurance and hardship. “I felt shaky from the story,” one said.
content: It is Sylvie Jean Baptiste’s job to check on patients during the 15-minute wait that follows their Covid-19 vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Dallas Police Officer Charged With 2 Counts of Capital Murder
description: The officer, Bryan Riser, was arrested on Thursday after a witness said the officer had hired him to kidnap and kill two people and then dump their bodies in a river, the police said.
content: A Dallas police officer was arrested on Thursday and charged with two counts of capital murder after a witness said that the officer had hired him to kidnap and kill two people and then dump their bodies in a river, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Adam’ Review: Beginning of a Beautiful Friendship
description: A widow welcomes a pregnant stranger into her home in this sentimental story mostly told unsentimentally.
content: In Maryam Touzani’s “Adam,” certain stylistic choices — a muted palette, the absence of a melodramatic score, hand-held camerawork — help temper sentimentality with verisimilitude. The movie tells a story of kindness given and returned. It opens with Samia (Nisrin Erradi) seeking a job as a hairdresser, and then as a maid, or really as anything. As a pregnant woman alone in Casablanca, she needs work and a place to stay — and encounters mainly indifference and judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Before Oprah’s Interview With Harry and Meghan, Royal Accusations Fly
description: CBS is releasing tantalizing video clips of the couple, while scalding allegations are coming from Buckingham Palace staff members.
content: The big face-off isn’t until Sunday, but the pregame skirmishes have been raging on both sides of the Atlantic for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Walrus and the Whistleblower’ Review: The Fight to Free a Friend
description: An animal trainer turned activist strives to end sea mammal captivity in this documentary that could use a sharper frame on its subject.
content: In Marineland, the sprawling aquatic park in Niagara Falls, Ontario, lives a walrus named Smooshi. Concerns for the sea mammal’s well-being form the core of the documentary “The Walrus and the Whistleblower,” which follows the former trainer Phil Demers’s fight to free Smooshi from her captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Transgender Woman Expelled From South Korean Army Is Found Dead
description: Byeon Hee-su, who was declared unfit to serve last year after her gender-reassignment surgery, had sued to be reinstated.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — A transgender woman who was expelled by the South Korean military last year after her gender-reassignment surgery has been found dead at her home south of Seoul, the police said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Boogie’ Review: There’s No Laughing in Basketball
description: Hoop dreams intertwine with Chinese-American identity in this coming-of-age drama from Eddie Huang.
content: Basketball is no laughing matter in the coming-of-age drama “Boogie.” Boogie Chin (Taylor Takahashi) is a basketball prodigy playing on his New York City high school’s mediocre team. His dream is to play in the N.B.A., but uncertainty over his college prospects makes Boogie’s future a constant subject of negotiation at home. Boogie’s mother wants security, and his father wants to keep dreaming. Boogie wants to prove himself to anyone who thinks he’s not worth the investment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Spieth and Fowler: Golf Prodigies Seek a Way Back From the Wilderness
description: Not so long ago Jordan Spieth and Rickie Fowler were ascending PGA Tour stars. Now they feel each other’s pain and trade notes. Can they get their grooves back?
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — It is remarkably difficult to be great at the highest level of golf at a young age. It is even harder to fail at golf after early triumphs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Signs of Life
description: Businesses say that people are preparing to go out again.
content: Almost a year ago — on March 11, to be exact — the World Health Organization officially declared that the spread of the coronavirus was a pandemic. Lockdowns and social distancing soon became a fact of life, and companies that rely on people gathering and moving around were hit hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Coming 2 America’ Review: Comedic Royalty
description: More than 30 years later, Eddie Murphy and Arsenio Hall reunite for a return trip from Zamunda to New York.
content: Breaking away from a lavish palace party meant to celebrate his engagement, Lavelle Junson (Jermaine Fowler), the newly minted crown prince of Zamunda, complains about the state of Hollywood filmmaking. He never says what kinds of movies he does like, but he’s vocal in his disdain for superhero spectacles and “sequels that nobody asked for.” Mirembe (Nomzamo Mbatha), his royal groomer and love interest, disagrees.
